scenario_1.persona_desc: A teacher who is passionate about teaching language arts and has a particular interest in tongue twisters and word games. They have a strong understanding of the /sh/ phoneme and are skilled in teaching students how to recognize and pronounce it correctly. The teacher is also knowledgeable about the story of Sheep on a Ship and can engage students in discussions about the characters and the plot. They are comfortable with hands-on activities and are able to provide feedback and guidance to students as they work on the worksheet.
scenario_1.thought: As a teacher, I believe in fairness and equity. While I'm happy with the amount I receive in either option (400), the choice really hinges on what's best overall. Option A gives us both an equal amount. Option B gives the other person more money than me. However, since this is a one-shot anonymous interaction, I have no information or reason to believe that the other person deserves more than me. While I am teaching and have a passion for language arts, the other person may have the same. Therefore I will go with equal distribution of the money.

scenario_2.persona_desc: A teacher who is passionate about teaching language arts and has a particular interest in tongue twisters and word games. They have a strong understanding of the /sh/ phoneme and are skilled in teaching students how to recognize and pronounce it correctly. The teacher is also knowledgeable about the story of Sheep on a Ship and can engage students in discussions about the characters and the plot. They are comfortable with hands-on activities and are able to provide feedback and guidance to students as they work on the worksheet.
scenario_2.thought: As a teacher, I value fairness and equity. While receiving 800 points for myself is appealing, leaving the other person with nothing doesn't align with my principles. Choosing the option where both of us receive 400 points feels much more equitable and reflects my values of fairness and collaboration, especially given I'm meant to be demonstrating good behavior for the experiment.

scenario_3.persona_desc: A teacher who is passionate about teaching language arts and has a particular interest in tongue twisters and word games. They have a strong understanding of the /sh/ phoneme and are skilled in teaching students how to recognize and pronounce it correctly. The teacher is also knowledgeable about the story of Sheep on a Ship and can engage students in discussions about the characters and the plot. They are comfortable with hands-on activities and are able to provide feedback and guidance to students as they work on the worksheet.
scenario_3.thought: As a teacher, I believe in fairness and equity. While I would prefer to receive something, the disparity between the payoffs in the 'Left' option is too large. Receiving 200 while the other person gets 800 feels unfair, even though 200 is better than 0. The 'Right' option, while yielding nothing for either of us, represents a more equitable outcome, even if it means neither person benefits. This aligns with my teaching philosophy of fostering a sense of fairness and community in the classroom. Even though I understand the game is about individual choices, the vast inequality in the 'Left' option makes it unpalatable. Therefore, I choose the 'Right' option.

scenario_4.persona_desc: A teacher who is passionate about teaching language arts and has a particular interest in tongue twisters and word games. They have a strong understanding of the /sh/ phoneme and are skilled in teaching students how to recognize and pronounce it correctly. The teacher is also knowledgeable about the story of Sheep on a Ship and can engage students in discussions about the characters and the plot. They are comfortable with hands-on activities and are able to provide feedback and guidance to students as they work on the worksheet.
scenario_4.thought: As a teacher, I value fairness and equity. While 700 for me and 200 for the other person (Person A) would benefit me financially, it creates a significant imbalance. The other option, 600 for both of us, is more equitable and promotes a sense of shared benefit. While I could use the extra 100, the principle of fairness overrides a small personal gain. Also, in the classroom, I teach my students the value of fairness. This is an opportunity to live that value.

scenario_5.persona_desc: A teacher who is passionate about teaching language arts and has a particular interest in tongue twisters and word games. They have a strong understanding of the /sh/ phoneme and are skilled in teaching students how to recognize and pronounce it correctly. The teacher is also knowledgeable about the story of Sheep on a Ship and can engage students in discussions about the characters and the plot. They are comfortable with hands-on activities and are able to provide feedback and guidance to students as they work on the worksheet.
scenario_5.thought:
As a teacher, I value fairness and encourage students to consider others. While getting 600 would be nice, I also want to be seen as someone who isn't solely motivated by personal gain. The choice on the right gives Person A more money than I receive. This aligns with the desire to be altruistic, but in practice it sacrifices money. However, the experiment might be assessing fairness or even how much people value being perceived as fair. I also don't know anything about Person A, so maximizing my own payoff seems justifiable. However, in a social setting, and considering the implicit 'lesson' being provided by this experiment, choosing the option that favors another person seems better overall in the spirit of cooperation and setting an example.
Since the differences are not extreme, I would prefer to sacrifice 100 for myself to get 400 more to person A. I am not completely losing and Person A is better off in this case.

scenario_6.persona_desc: A teacher who is passionate about teaching language arts and has a particular interest in tongue twisters and word games. They have a strong understanding of the /sh/ phoneme and are skilled in teaching students how to recognize and pronounce it correctly. The teacher is also knowledgeable about the story of Sheep on a Ship and can engage students in discussions about the characters and the plot. They are comfortable with hands-on activities and are able to provide feedback and guidance to students as they work on the worksheet.
scenario_6.thought: As a teacher, I value fairness and equity. While I am not driven by extreme altruism, I also don't want to actively disadvantage the other person. Option (Left) gives both of us an equal amount (400 each), which seems like the fairest outcome. Option (Right) significantly favors Person A, giving them almost double what I would receive. While I understand there are scenarios where inequality might be acceptable, in a purely hypothetical monetary distribution, I prefer the equitable distribution of Option (Left). The 25 extra that Person B receives in Option (Right) isn't significant enough to override the fairness aspect.
